reviewText:
Although I like the concept of a game exploring some of the rewards of hiking and climbing mountains, this ended up being way too pretentious and even less enjoyable than Dear Esther (one of the few games similar to this one); though I might be biased because I've never liked poetry, so I might not be the target audience.

The environmental and visual aesthetics are very good in many respects, but not as diverse and awe-inspiring as Dear Esther in my opinion. Although this is very linear like Dear Esther, Drizzlepath has much more of an open-world feel with less invisible walls. The atmospheric sound-effects were too few and far between for the first half of the game, which drew too much attention to the monotonous footsteps in the midst of near-silence; whereas Dear Esther is chock full of immersive environmental sound-effects every step of the way.

The musical interludes were for the most part too short, too similar and too infrequent to be enjoyable/rewarding for passing through checkpoints; longer songs would've slightly improved the game imo. Given that both Dear Esther and Drizzlepath are very similar types of games, and both have roughly equivalent pretentious elements, I'd recommend getting Dear Esther instead for the extra immersiveness, or Drizzlepath for the extra open-world feel; or both if you want any game that's more interactive poetic film than game.

Please, if any game-devs are reading this, improve on this genre by making similar games that actually reward exploration, while offering thought-provoking philosophical dialogue rather than (imo) inconsequentially poetic nonsense; a pretentious example being void of finite infinity.""

reviewText:
A Breathtaking visual landscape and stunning background are your first experiences in Drizzlepath, as you climb out of the water and begin your journey. The first 10 to 15 minutes of gameplay will consist of moving your character in the First-Person perspective, along a twisting, winding path, as you traverse the Island from one Biome into another, with only music and a narration-style monologue accompanying you as you reach various checkpoints. The Narration is done in a heavily accented English, making it difficult to understand at times, as your attention keeps being drawn to your surroundings.

Sometimes the path forward no longer appears obvious, but if you get off course you can load from a previous checkpoint. You will pass by abandoned buildings, old ruins, and more as you make the slow, steady climb.
Even though the beginning is slow, I found it to actually be very fulfilling. It isn't often we get to play a visually stunning game and just enjoy the surroundings without being attacked or the need to interact with others. The music is simplistic, consisting of acoustic guitars, andI found the experience leading up to the Camp to be calming and soothing.

Eventually you will reach a camp in a snow covered mountain area, where the GAME ENDS. That's right, that's it. Drizzlepath is a Walking Simulator. Once I reached the camp, I thought okay, this must be where the journey, story, or adventure begins. No. This is where the game ends. This is sad in so many ways, because it would have been a wonderful beginning to a game, had there actually been a game once you reached the camp. I wanted so much to write a thumbs up review, because the visuals alone make it worth that, but I can't in good conscience give a thumbs up to a game where the entire objective is to walk from one place to another. If you are interested in doing that, pick up a game like Skyrim, and walk around. You will get stunning visuals and have the option as well as ability to do other things and actually play a game as well.

As much as it pains me, Thumbs Down.

Walk. Listen.

Walk up the drizzle path, listen to the heavily accented female voice tell you hard to understand poetic prose (no subtitles), listen to guitar music. If it takes an hour, that's  alot - it took me less. Jump once or more, if you like.

Cryengine or not, it wasn't immersive. It wasn't thought-provoking. I don't even know what part of the world this mountain is modeled after, the Andes? but it's a mostly linear path, with visible and invisble walls (try swimming anyplace) and some surreal objects sprinkled around. I couldn't make sense of it and, by the end, was glad that it was over. Since the narration is just soundbites and music triggered at certain points along the path, and since it bears little relation to your actual surroundings, no amount of exploration was able to help me make more sense of it.

The game lagged a bit on my system. It generated an error log 20 MB in size consisting mostly of bbox errors, which reeks of shoddy modeling. There's a German localization .pak, but I found no way to actually activate it - there aren't any in-game options nor can be done via Steam.

I do love exploration, but a picture book of the Andes[www.flickr.com] or some other mountain paths[www.flickr.com] plus a bit of good guitar music would have served me better.

I recommend this for 0.99 or less if you like the soundtrack (check the trailer), it is included with the game.

reviewText:
You control an unknown man as he slowly ascends the Mountain of Fire: as you walk along the path you're accompanied by bits of music and a female voice.
While looking extremely pretty the world of Drizzlepath is sadly void of content and what's there is hard to make out and/ or too cryptic to be engaging.

PROS:

-the graphics are truly nice

-the short tunes that accompany your walk are very, very good

-the narrator's spanish accent was quite alluring

-gives you quite some space to explore off the beaten path

CONS:

-the graphics also have several problems such as warping textures, a poor draw distance that leads to noticeable foliage and texture pop-in, and a somewhat buggy character shadow

-as alluring as it may be the narrator's accent makes it quite hard to understand her lines

-the audio mix is problematic, in several instances the music drowns out the narrator's voice

-lack of subtitles makes things even worse when you try to make out what the narrator is saying

-the actual narrative (from what lines one manages to understand due to the aforementioned problems) is pretty cryptic and lacks substance

-exploring is mostly useless, apart from a few easter eggs there's not much else (all the narrative occurs on the path)

-very short, you can be done in an hour or even less if you don't explore around too much

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=546704094

Drizzlepath is a truly nice looking game, the landscape looks great if no graphical glitches or problems are present: the music is also very nice with a warm guitar sometimes accompanied by piano or harmonica, in fact it was so nice I wished there was more than just the short pieces you hear whenever the narrator is speaking.

Sadly though once you're past its great graphics and soundtrack there's not much actual content even considering all the leeway the walking simulator genre gets: the narrator is hard to understand due to the accent, her lines are often overwhelmed by the loud music and what little you can make out of them is so vague and enigmatic that it's hard to feel engaged in any way. I'm sorry but there's a fine line between wanting to be ambiguous, forcing the player to try and make sense of things, and coming out as deliberately obscure just for the sake of it.

I'm sure the graphics and relaxing walk will be enough for some, and in fact there's a good amount of positive reviews, but for me there's simply not enough meaningful content to be had and this turns Drizzlepath into a beautiful looking but equally empty experience, one I can't recommend.

Overall while I was playing through it I kept finding myself knitpicking lots of little issues with the game... but I didn't stop playing it.  It was interesting enough that it was worth seeing through to the end.  There were some very pretty set up scenes, and a few occations when the surroundings were interesting enough that I took some detours to explore the environment more (note to the developer: you may want to add clipping to the lighthouse).

reviewText:
SUMMARY: An odd, atmospheric game about simple exploration that is strangely compelling.  Worth getting if you want to try something about mood and wandering, and support an experimental game for a very low price.  Otherwise, probably not for you.

You know those moments in Skyrim and other sandbox games where you just wandered around and wondered?  Drizzlepath is what happens when someone makes a game out of it - and there's more too it than it sounds.

The idea of the game is to have you travel to the top of a mysterious mountain, or wander around aimlessly and see the scenery, or both.  However as you play you find strange and interesting things, a mysterious narrator discusses your past in surreal terms, and moodly music suddenly plays.  It's an experience that is both rather realistic due to the visuals, and dreamlike and weird.

My reaction to the game was, in this order:
1) This looks cool.
2) This is kind of boring.
3) I'll see what happens if I follow that path.
4) What's going on?
5) I think I'll keep going to find out.
6) Woah, wait what was that?
7) Wow.  That was kind of neat.

It's a short, well-crafted experience that I found compelling.  You can play through it in about an hour and get to the end
date:
though I can see some people may want to replay to see what they missed.  There's no sense of rush or urgency.

The biggest flaw I think is the lack of subtitles - at times it was hard to make out what the narrator was saying.

The biggest advantages are the nice visuals and the great soundtrack.

Is it perfect?  No.  It's an experimental type game, perfection isn't the goal. However it did achieve something - namely it got me curious enough and engrossed enough to play what is basically a walking simulator in order to see what's up.    I'd say I got my money's worth.

If this sounds intriguing, remember it's only about $4, so set aside an hour, get the game, and enjoy the experience.

Drizzlepath is essentially a Dear Esther clone that tries to use all the positives from that particular experience and perform not so well on all fronts. From a visual standpoint, it's absolutely excellent, but it doesn't match the level of execution or narrative it's presumed source of influence achieved.

Whilst I can't deny that CryEngine 3 is a damn beautiful thing to look at, getting the game set up to begin with was a bit awkward, with CryEngine itself crashing on multiple occasions until I got a lucky break and it kept running (this is with a mid/upper range PC as well). The game itself looks to be a little heavy on system requirements, as some framerate drops were quite noticeable in the odd place where activity is going on in the background.

Whilst compositionally the music isn't bad, but it's incredibly jarring 90% of the time and completely fights against the atmosphere that's been set in the scenery that surrounds you. This killed a lot of the immersive experience that games of this type are supposed to be strong at delivering. Once those passages pass, even the background ambience is fairly mute which meant outside of those distracting segments with untelligible narrative, you were headbobbing in more or less complete silence.

reviewText:
Cheap Walking sim

I like a good walking sim, unfortunately, though I do appreciate the effort and organisation it takes to make and publish a simple game, this is not one of them. This is a bad Dear Esther clone. The screen shots are pretty because this is using a good engine, most of the work there has been doubtless done by the engine creators, not this game's developer.

- Like Dear Esther you are basically on a path to the top of the island.
- Like Dear Esther there is nothing to do but walk and hear dialogue.
- Like Dear Esther there is music in the background.

However, the  *island* is a simple height field. There’s no beautiful caves, no interesting rock features, the vegetation is either simple grass and bushes or complex trees. I think I decided the level design was no work of art, when I randomly came across a fridge-freezer, just randomly located on a hill just off the path. No music, no dialogue, no interactions, no effect on the story and no relation to it. At least a rock is part of the overall canvas of the background. This was a random object placed for no reason.

There is absolutely very little cohesion to the music, there’s a lot of guitar pieces, but then there’s also some quite dramatic synth based pieces and even a full-band-with-drummer-and-bass-player track somewhere. I believe music is meant to help shape your mood or accentuate the landscape. Here, it was too loud (there’s no sound options to reduce it), and contrasts at most levels with the game.

The dialogue is horrible. It's full of clichéd phrases that would have any creative writing teacher committing suicide. reviewText:
I like walking simulators, they tend to be relaxing, beautiful & a way to express a variety of stories that can run the range from bizarre & non-sensical (The Void, Cylne) to humourous (The Stanley Parable) to mysterious/twisty with some light heartbreak  (The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, Among The Sleep) to uplifting coming of age/teen drama (Gone Home/Life Is Strange) to long descenting rants into rash decisions (The Old City: Leviathan, Dear Esther).

This is probably more in line with Dear Esther, but they allowed a lot more straying from the path because of allowing swimming long distances & climbing slopes; I would have thought this would mean there was either more to the game or at least they expected this to happen, but most of the areas outisde of the intended path show how much they didn't expect players to explore.
I fell through the ground a number of times into underground lakes of not fully rendered water with tree textures criss crossing the top, groups of trees floating feet from the ground, forests of trees that looked great from a distance but up close would make Duke 3D blush; even areas players not intending to test the limits of the game might explore come off badly like some of the really large rock formations which would be cool to take screenshots of & from atop of, are poorly textured up close.

The story was preety good, if this was out before Dear Esther, I wouldn't have a comparison point & this would fare better.
If you want the most enjoyment out of it, don't explore any, let the story happen & you'll probably be okay with spending the $4.

Played on Very High until it crashed & didn't save my checkpoint & then on High, got the same graphical oddities I whined about at the start.

reviewText:
Well, there's an hour I won't get back...

Feels like an abandoned tech demo. Almost like a Far Cry map but without any of the 'interaction' or game associated to it. The young lady narrators heavily accented wittering didn't enhance things for me either.

Not sure about the whole walking sim genre, although I did enjoy Dear Esther because of the atmosphere and story. Sadly this is no Dear Esther.

I know there are those who will say that going for a walk in reality has no point (other than the exercise benefits) so why should this need more on a PC but, even on oculus rift, this needs additional content/interaction.

If this had been linked to say a Wii Fit style running/walking sim then it may have been better suited and have some validity. As it is, the seemingly pointless wandering really start to irritate rather than relax me, which I'm presuming is the opposite of what the 'game' was designed to do.

The novelty wore off after 5 mins and then the laborious trudging set in. There must be something new to see or do over this next hill I hoped... but alas not.

I probably won't be returning to this one. An exploring sim with no point is, well, just pointless.

It does initially have nice enough graphics but they do start to look VERY 'samey' after just a few minutes and the landmarks that have been scattered around are too infrequent and uninteresting to hold my attention and give me impetus to continue the trudging.

I don't want to sound negative I wanted to like this one, I really did, but it's just not for me.

Maybe the sequel Genie will add more content and improve the experience but I won't be spending 5 quid to find out.
